div.p: PARISH CHURCHES turn'd into conventicles, BY Serving God therein, and wor≈øhiping him otherwi≈øe then according to the e≈øtabli≈øhed Liturgy and Practice of the Church of England.
IN PARTICULAR, By reading the Communion Service, or any part thereof in the Desk.

OR Plain Rea≈øons and undeniable Authorities alledged for the reading of the ≈øecond Service, or the Communion Service, when there is no Communion, at the Altar, or Holy Table, in an Epi≈øtle dedicated to all the Reverend Clergy of the Church of England who read it in the Desk.
By Richard Hart, a Friend to all the conformable Clergy and Laity of the true and Apo≈øtolical Church of England by Law E≈øtabli≈øhed.
LONDON, Printed by Ralph Holt, for Obadiah Blagrave, at the Bear in St. Paul's Church-Yard. 1683.

TO ≈øeek out an Excu≈øe of this my Boldne≈øs, and to arm the Acknowledgment of a Fault with the Rea≈øons for it, might better ≈øhew I knew I did ami≈øs, than any way dimini≈øh the Attempt: therefore I intend to carry no other Olive-Branch of Interce≈ø≈øion than a cleer manife≈øtation of the Truth of ≈øuch things wherein I do humbly conceive you Err, ≈øome of you; not wilfully perhaps, yet for want of a due and ≈øerious Con≈øideration of the great Obligation of humane Laws in things which in their own nature are indifferent. One of which is the place for reading of the ≈øecond Service; which place, without all doubt, is a thing in its own nature indifferent: But when a lawful Authority appoints a certain place, although in its own nature the place remains ≈øtill indifferent, yet the u≈øe of that place is not indifferent, but becomes nece≈ø≈øary by rea≈øon of the command, to which the nece≈ø≈øity of Obedience is in≈øeparably annexed.

If this be a fal≈øe Po≈øition, I have nothing more to ≈øay, but if it be true, then do you err in point of Practice, which is not according to the e≈øtabli≈øh'd Rule, our Church appointing one certain place, and you reading in another; and ≈øo by this means teaching the People this dangerous Principle, that things indifferent
in their own Nature, remain ≈øo as to their u≈øe after a lawful Command, for the doing, or not doing of any ≈øuch indifferent things, as they were before ≈øuch Command or Prohibition. A Principle which undermines the Foundation of the whole Church; and being once admitted, leaves us naked and defencele≈øs again≈øt all the Weapons that are or may be formed, either by the Papi≈øt or Puritan, again≈øt the mo≈øt glorious Church in the World. And if we, who pro≈øe≈øs our ≈øelves to be Sons of the Church of England, ≈øhould embrace this mi≈øchievous Tenet, our Church will be ≈øo much militant again≈øgt her ≈øelf, that her Enemies will in a very ≈øhort time become Triumphant. They ≈øeeing your practice evidently built upon this ≈øandy Fo ‚Ä¢ ndation, do on all ≈øides hit us in the Teeth with the≈øe things, and laugh us to ≈øcorn.

Why do you charge us with Nonconformity and Di≈øobedience to humane Laws, which are but things indifferent, notwith≈øtanding the Command. (≈øay they) for do not mo≈øt of your Clergy e≈øteem them as ≈øuch, when they omit what Rite and Ceremony they plea≈øe, though never ≈øo ≈øtrictly injoined by the ≈øupreme Authority? Do the≈øe things oblige our Con≈øciences, and are theirs only free? If it be ≈øo, then we perceive plainly that the only way to enjoy liberty of Con≈øcience, is to be a Clergy-Man of the Church of England.

Now what ≈øhall we ≈øay to the≈øe things? If we deny the matter of Fact, our Church Enemies charge us with Impudence, if we confe≈øs it (as to keep our ≈øelves from lying we are forc'd to do) then they charge our reverend Clergy with the ≈øame Crimes we u≈øually appropriate to the greate≈øt Phanatick, viz. Di≈øobedience to the lawful Magi≈øtrate, and Non-conformity to the e≈øtabli≈øh'd Orders of the Church. How
to avoid the Horns of this Dilemma, I do ≈øincerely declare I know not.

I ≈øhould be very glad if any of you would be pleas'd to tell me a full An≈øwer that I may give to the≈øe trouble≈øom People, who have gagg'd me ≈øo often with the≈øe things, that I am altogether become dumb, and am a≈øhamed to receive ≈øo many Baffles from tho≈øe Fools who make a mock of Sin.

I thank God I can defend my ≈øelf well enough again≈øt all the frivolous and captious Exceptions which have been either made or taken by the Recu≈øant or the Di≈ø≈øenter again≈øt the e≈øtabli≈øhed Doctrine, Di≈øcipline and Wor≈øhip of the Church of England; but if they talk to me of any thing that is ≈øaid or done in our Churches, which is not warranted by the XXXIX. Articles, by the Book of Canons, by the Book of Common Prayer, or by the con≈øtant univer≈øal Practice of the Catholick Church of Chri≈øt; they had as good talk to me of the Roman Breviary, or the Engli≈øh Directory, and I can as ≈øoon ju≈øtify the ≈øaying, either of them in our Churches, as any thing I have before mentioned.

True it is, that we have a mo≈øt excellent Liturgy e≈øtabli≈øhed by the Law of the Land, but in very many places little or no care had that the Subjects may have it whole and intire, without mangling and curtailing in ≈øuch a ≈øhameful manner that by the≈øe ≈øacrilegious ways our ≈øacred Book of Common Prayer is become contemptible, and the People are come to this pa≈øs, even downright to declare their abhorrence of our religious A≈ø≈øemblies; when in≈øtead of paying that ≈øolemn Wor≈øhip to God, which by the Laws of our Nation are devoted to him, we wor≈øhip him after our own Imaginations, and hereby offer him the Sacrifice of Fools, which he will in no wi≈øe accept.

Although I could in≈øtance in ≈øundry Particulars, yet at this time I ≈øhall onely name one, which is reading the Communion Service in the Desk, whereby you take upon you to break an authori≈øed Order of our Church, and to make a new one: The appointment of which Order pertaineth not to private Men (as our Church ≈øaith very truly) therefore no Man ought to take in hand, or pre≈øume to appoint or alter any publick or common Order in Chri≈øt's Church, except he be lawfully called and authorized thereunto.

Either you believe this to be true or fal≈øe; if true, then you wilfully and contemptuou≈øly tran≈øgre≈øs and break a common Order and Di≈øcipline when≈øoever you omit or alter a Rite or Ceremony appointed by the Church, which though in its ≈øelf con≈øidered, is but a ≈ømall thing, yet by rea≈øon of the Contempt, that is in≈øeparably annexed to the Offence in a Per≈øon knowing, and being verily per≈øwaded of the Truth hereof, it is no ≈ømall Offence before God, that is in plain Engli≈øh, it is a very great Sin.

Now if it ≈øhould ≈øo happen that any of you are of another Per≈øwa≈øion, and ≈øo you are Di≈ø≈øenters in your Judgment, as well as in your Practice, why then did you ≈øub≈øcribe to the ≈øecond Article mentioned in the XXXVI. Canon, and play fa≈øt and loo≈øe with God Almighty, and put Tricks upon your own Mother the Church of England? Do you think that God will be mocked, or permit his holy Spou≈øe to be cheated? How can you, or any other be ≈øaid to u≈øe the Form pre≈øcribed in publick Prayer and Admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and none other, which you have promi≈øed to do by your Sub≈øcription, which is a ≈øacred Tie, and yet immediately after willingly omit, or alter any one Rite or Ceremony, without a great perfidiou≈øne≈øs!

As to the Point of reading the Communion Service when there is no Communion, I do po≈øitively a≈ø≈øert, that it is appointed by our Church to be read at the North ≈øide of the Holy Table, and that who≈øoever reads it at any other place, breaks the Order of our Church, and if he doth it through his private Judgment willingly and purpo≈øely (as he cannot be pre≈øumed to do otherwi≈øe who is fully convinced that the Church hath ≈øo appointed it) he doth not only offend again≈øt the common order of the Church, but hurteth the Authority of the Magi≈øtrate, and woundeth the Con≈øciences of the weak Brethren!

Herein I have two ≈øorts of Per≈øons to deal withal, one plainly confe≈ø≈øing, that 'tis-commanded by the Church, and thereby ≈øaving me the trouble of a Proof, but ≈øaying withal that he is at liberty notwith≈øtanding the Command, and he offers ≈øome ≈øeeming Rea≈øons for his altering the appointed Place, and ≈øays they are ≈øufficient to ju≈øtify his Practice both before God and Man, and whether they be ≈øo or no, you will ≈øee by and by.

There is another ≈øort of men who knowing not how to ju≈øtify their pre≈øent Practice contrary to a plain Injunction of Authority, are forced to make u≈øe of an Index Expurgatorius, and having thereby in their own Conceit quite expung'd the Rubrick as to this Purpo≈øe, confidently tell me there is no ≈øuch Command when there is no Communion, therefore no di≈øobedience to that Authority which they own, and are both ready and willing to obey.

To every one of you (dear Sirs) who own the thing which others deny, I mu≈øt an≈øwer with an ex ore tuo te Judico: for you ingeniou≈øly confe≈øs that 'tis commanded by the Church, and yet at the ≈øame time mo≈øt di≈øingeniou≈øly prefer a corrupt Practice of ≈øome
ill principled men before your known Duty.

And for this you make ≈øeveral Pleas. Fir≈øt, you ≈øay 'tis the Cu≈øtom of mo≈øt Pari≈øh Churches to read the ≈øecond Service in the Desk: and Cu≈øtom in the major part of any Society, hath the force of a Law, and a Law which is introduced by Cu≈øtom, is as much a Law as any Statute Law of the Land, becau≈øe a Law doth not recipere magis & minus, and if you do obey that Law which Cu≈øtom hath made ≈øo, you are as much obedient to the Law, as he that obeys an Act of Parliament. But how weak and in≈øufficient this Plea is, judg you your own ≈øelves, when you have well con≈øidered the fal≈øe Notions of ≈øuch a Cu≈øtom, which you too fa≈øt do run away with, not making any di≈øtinction between corruptela, and con≈øuetudo, and little regarding the ≈ømall force ≈øuch a Cu≈øtom (≈øetting a≈øide the Corruption) hath to ≈øway any Mans Judgment who is rightly informed of the truth of this matter.

Now certainly mo≈øt true it is, that a con≈øtant univer≈øal Cu≈øtom or Practice of a whole National Church hath the force of a Law, and ought without all doubt to be ob≈øerved; but then you mu≈øt take this along with you, provided that no po≈øitive Law of the Kingdom intervene to annul that Cu≈øtom, Practice, or what you will call it, otherwi≈øe the Rule is fal≈øe: For to plead Cu≈øtom again≈øt po≈øitive Law, is to plead that which was the Law again≈øt that which is the Law; the ≈øole intent of all po≈øitive Laws, being to take away the binding power of all cu≈øtomary Laws to the contrary, otherwi≈øe there would be two Laws in being at one and the ≈øame time, commanding the one contrary to the other, which would certainly breed that confu≈øion which all po≈øitive Laws are de≈øigned to prevent.

I Pray Gentlemen be plea≈øed to con≈øider what Mi≈øchief you do both to Church and State, by preferring ≈øuch a Cu≈øtom as this before an e≈øtabli≈øhed Law to the contrary: Do not you by this means turn our golden Liturgy into a leaden Directory, and the be≈øt of Churches into the wor≈øt of Conventicles? You may laugh as much you plea≈øe, but this is a great Truth, becau≈øe it is neither the Place, nor the Number of Per≈øons meeting together that makes a Conventicle, for the≈øe may be Riots, Routs, or unlawful A≈ø≈øemblies: but that which doth con≈øtitute it a Conventicle, and from which it receives its true Denomination, is the meeting in any Place above ≈øuch a limited Number, and Serving God otherwi≈øe than according to the e≈øtabli≈øhed Liturgy and Practice of the Church of England, which may be done in a Church as well as a Barn, as ≈øad Experience tells. It is only the Ob≈øervation, or non-Ob≈øervation of all the Orders, Rites, and Ceremonies (and none other) which are appointed in and by the Common Prayer and Book of Canons, which gives it the Denomination of a Church or Conventicle. If all the Orders be regularly ob≈øerved without Addition or Diminution, either in Matter or Form, 'tis a true Church, and a right Church: but if any thing be Said, Sung, or done, in Church, or in private Hou≈øes (where there are above ≈øuch a Number as the Law appoints) as the publick Wor≈øhip of God, which is not warranted by the Book of Common Prayer, or by ≈øome Law of the ≈øupreme Governour both in Church and State, although hereby it cea≈øes not to be a true Church, yet it cea≈øes to be a right Church, and commences to be a true Conventicle, for I know no Medium between a right Church, and a true Conventicle, every Meeting upon the pretence of the Exerci≈øe
of Religion; being the one or the other.

And ≈øo every Per≈øon in Holy Orders that officiates at Divine Service, is either a thorough Conformi≈øt, or a Non-conformi≈øt, I know no medium in an E≈øtabli≈øhed Church (as ours is) but if there be, I de≈øire to be informed of the≈øe things, to wit, how many, or how few of the e≈øtabli≈øhed Prayers may be ≈øaid? How many of the Rites and Ceremonies may be u≈øed? Which may be omitted, which altered? Which neither omitted nor altered? And yet the ≈øame Per≈øon doing or omitting any of the≈øe things, may be, and remain a true Conformi≈øt, for if they be not limited to a certain number, then he that u≈øes only the Lords Prayer, u≈øes part of the Book of Common Prayer, and the mo≈øt material part too, and may as truly be e≈øteemed as true a Conformi≈øt as he that u≈øes a great deal more, and yet falls ≈øhort of the whole, either as to Matter of Form; for who≈øoever he be that alters or dimini≈øhes willingly in either, he is ≈øo far a Nonconformi≈øt, and how much farther he will proceed, no body knows but him≈øelf; but this we know by common Experience, break Ice in one place, it will crack in a great many more. He that wilfully breaks the ≈ømalle≈øt order of the Church, is fle≈øht for greater matters. How true therefore is that ≈øaying, MINIMUM NON EST NON NEGLIGERE MINIMA? And what a great deal of Mi≈øchief in the Church would this ≈ømall Sentence prevent, if it were believed and put in Practice? for then there would not be ≈øo many Secundum u≈øum's as there are nowadayes. Heretofore it was only Secundum u≈øum Sarum, ≈øecundum u≈øum Hereforden≈øem, ≈øecundum u≈øum Bangoren≈øem, ≈øecundum u≈øum Eboracen≈øem, ≈øecundum u≈øum Lincolnien≈øem; the≈øe were all prime Places, Cathedralls all, and yet at the beginning of
the Reformation this was thought to be a great Grievance.

But now every Pari≈øh, be it never ≈øo incon≈øiderable, pre≈øcribes to a Secundum u≈øum; ≈øecundum U≈øum this Pari≈øh, ≈øecundum u≈øum that Pari≈øh; and ≈øo you may go on, and name all the Pari≈øhes of England as far as the Town of Berwick upon Tweed, and ≈øo many ≈øeveral Churches, ≈øo many ≈øecundum u≈øum's there are, and yet the Rule by which they be all to walk, is all one and the ≈øame. Now from henceforth (≈øay's the Church of England in her Preface concerning the Service of the Church) all the whole Realm ≈øhall have but one U≈øe, and for this very purpo≈øe was a Liturgy compo≈øed to remedy the great Diver≈øities in ≈øaying and ≈øinging in Churches, a Remedy very ≈øagely contrived, but to no purpo≈øe, becau≈øe never put in Practice. So much for that.

The next Plea I have heard ≈øome of you make u≈øe of, is, that the Bi≈øhop of your Dioce≈øs doth di≈øpen≈øe with your Obedience as to ≈øeveral Rubricks, and in particular to this, which is a plain Confe≈ø≈øion that 'tis enjoin'd by the ≈øupreme Authority, otherwi≈øe, what need is there of a Di≈øpen≈øation? which being ≈øo, what Authority hath the Bi≈øhop, or all the Bi≈øhops together (I ≈øay this with humble Submi≈ø≈øion to that Holy Order, for which no Man hath a greater Veneration than my ≈øelf) what Authority, I ≈øay, have they to di≈øpen≈øe with a Duty injoyned by Act of Parliament? ≈øure I am, that they may as well Di≈øpen≈øe with the woollen Act, or the Act prohibiting Iri≈øh Cattel, as with the Act of Uniformity. Doth not the Book of Common Prayer it≈øelf, which is e≈øtabli≈øhed by the ≈øaid Act, re≈øtrain all Dioce≈øans from making any order concerning any Doubt ari≈øing about the U≈øe and Practice of any thing in the Book, any order that is
contrary to any thing contained in this Book?

Now from hence I argue, If the Communion Service be not appointed by the Rubrick to be read at the North ≈øide of the Table when there is no Communion, and ≈øo the reading it in the Desk be not contrary to any thing contained in the book, why do you require a needle≈øs Di≈øpen≈øation, and if it be contrary how can be Bi≈øhop grant it?

When publick Orders and Con≈øtitutions have been received, and have taken place, ≈øhall general Obedience thereunto cea≈øe to be exacted, in ca≈øe this or that private Per≈øon led with ≈øome probable Conceit, ≈øhould make open Declaration that A. B. Bi≈øhop of, &c. doth di≈øpen≈øe with me concerning ≈øuch a Rubrick? And although 'tis granted that the Bi≈øhop him≈øelf is a Per≈øon in a publick Charge and Authority, and all Curates are bound to obey him in omnibus licitis & hone≈øtis; yet if the Dioce≈øan ≈øhould command all under his Juri≈ødiction to read the Communion Service in the Desk, the Bi≈øhops Mandate without all doubt mu≈øt give place to the King's Laws, and in all ≈øuch Ca≈øes the King mu≈øt be obeyed, and not the Bi≈øhop, becau≈øe it is neither licitum nor hone≈øtum, to obey any ≈øubordinate Power, when the Supreme commands otherwi≈øe: Be≈øides, when publick con≈øent of the whole hath e≈øtabli≈øhed any thing, every Man's Judgment being thereunto compared, is private, how≈øoever his Calling be to ≈øome kind of publick Charge, otherwi≈øe there could be no means po≈ø≈øible to attain to any Peace or Quietne≈øs either in Church or State, unle≈øs the probable Voice of every intire Society or Body Politick, over-rule all private of like Nature in the ≈øame.

And this is our Ca≈øe exactly; for 'tis determined by the King with the Con≈øent of the three E≈øtates,
repre≈øenting the whole Body of the Kingdom, where the ≈øecond Service ≈øhall be ≈øaid; and this is not alterable according to our Laws, but by the ≈øame full Authority by which it was enacted; not by any ≈øingle Per≈øon, if he be a Subject, nor by any one of three E≈øtates, nor by all together without the King, which is ≈øufficient to over-rule the frivolous Plea of a Di≈øpen≈øation, which can never be defended without overturning the Government, by altering the Frame and Con≈øtitution thereof: to ≈øuch ≈øad Exigents are they reduced who undertake to defend what they have not beforehand well con≈øidered of: For who would have imagined, that ≈øo ≈ømall an Omi≈ø≈øion as this at fir≈øt ≈øight ≈øeems to be, ≈øhould ≈øwell to ≈øuch a mountainous Crime as to equal the Popes Pride in contending with the King for the Supremacy, and by little and little to ≈øubvert his Government: which puts me in mind of a Pa≈ø≈øage I have met with in Plutarch, which jumps even with the matter in hand.

Paulus Aemylius, a noble Roman, and one of the Con≈øuls, afterwards cho≈øen to be one of the number of Prie≈øts, whom the Romans called Augurs; when he did any thing belonging to his Office of Prie≈øthood, he did it with great Experience, Judgment, and Diligence; leaving all other Thoughts, and without omitting any ancient Ceremony, or adding to any new; contending oftentimes with his Companions in things which ≈øeemed light and of ≈ømall moment, declaring unto them that though we do pre≈øume the Gods are ea≈øy to be pacified, and that they readily pardon all Scapes and Faults committed by Negligence, yet if it were no more but for re≈øpect of Common-Wealths ≈øake, they ≈øhould not ≈ølightly, nor carele≈øly di≈ø≈øemble, nor pa≈øs over Faults committed in tho≈øe matters: For no Man (≈øaith he) at the fir≈øt, that committeth
